p: The translation of the coronavirus replicase genes from two large open reading frames (ORFs), rep1a and rep1b, allows the expression of two polyproteins, pp1a and pp1ab, utilizing a slippery sequence (5′-UUUAAAC-3′) and an RNA pseudoknot [ 68, 69]. The complicated composition of the pp1a and pp1ab polyproteins and the assembly of nsPs are described in detail by Fehr and Perlman [ 2]. Following the translation and assembly of the replicase complex, viral RNA synthesis from both genomic and subgenomic RNAs occurs. The latter serves as mRNAs for the structural and accessory genes [ 2]. In the 5′ untranslated region, there are cis-acting sequences such as stem–loop structures, which are important for viral RNA replication [ 70, 71, 72, 73]. An interesting feature of coronavirus replication relates to the fusing of the leader and body TRS segments during the production of subgenomic RNAs. Although originally thought to occur during positive-strand synthesis, a recent model suggests that RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) pauses at any of the body TRS sequences during the discontinuous extension of negative-strand RNA, followed by either continued elongation to the next TRS or switching to amplification of the leader sequence at the 5′ end [ 74, 75].
